review.title: On First-Order Model-Based Reasoning
review.abstract: Reasoning semantically in first-order logic is notoriously a challenge. This paper surveys a selection of {\em semantically-guided} or {\em model-based} methods that aim at meeting aspects of this challenge. For first-order logic we touch upon {\em resolution-based} methods, {\em tableaux-based} methods, {\em DPLL-inspired} methods, and we give a preview of a new method called SGGS, for {\em Semantically-Guided Goal-Sensitive} reasoning. For first-order theories we highlight {\em hierarchical} and {\em locality-based} methods, concluding with the recent {\em Model-Constructing satisfiability calculus}.
histories: To appear in Narciso Marti-Oliet, Peter Olveczky, and Carolyn Talcott (Eds.), "Logic, Rewriting, and Concurrency: Essays in Honor of Jose Meseguer" Springer, Lecture Notes in Computer Science, September 2015, 24 pages

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: In recent years, there has been a wave of model-based procedures of the first order, inspired in part by the success of model-based solutions for propositional satisfaction (SAT) and the satisfaction of modular theories (SMT).The core of these approaches is the conflict-driven clause learning (CDCL) version [52,62,88,60] of the Davis-Putnam-Logemann-Loveland (DPLL) model, in which the conflict-clause solution (CDCL) version [52,62,62,88,60] of the Davis-Putnam-Logemann-Loveland (DPLL) model for propositional logic [32] was proposed.

sections.heading: 2 Model-based Reasoning in First-Order Logic
sections.text: In this section, we cover semantic resolution, which represents early attempts to inject semantics into resolution; hypertableaux, which illustrate model-based thinking in tableaus, with applications to error diagnosis and descriptive logic; the model evolutionary calculation, which elevates the DPLL to first-order logic; and a new method called SGGS for semantic goal-sensitive thinking, which implements a first-order CDCL mechanism.

sections.heading: 3 Model-based Reasoning in First-Order Theories
sections.text: There are essentially two ways of thinking about a theory that is presented by a series of axioms: as a set of all theorems that are logical consequences of the axioms, or as a set of all interpretations that are models of the axioms. Obviously, the two are linked, but can lead to different ways of thinking, which we present by selecting methods in this section. We will discuss approaches that incorporate axioms in resolution, hierarchical and local theoretical thinking, and a newer method called Model-Constructing satisfiability calicus or MCsat.

sections.heading: 3.1 Building Theory Axioms into Resolution and Superposition
sections.text: The first theory analysed was equality: since the axioms of equality were subjected to dissolution or other systems of consequence to the logic of the first order, they led to an explosion of search space, paramodulation, superimposition and transcription were developed to convert equality into dissolution (e.g. [73.48.77.4.21] and chapters 7 and 9 in [76]). After equality was conquered, research on integration theories flourished (e.g. [72.66.54.49.36.40.53.30]). Theories of equality axiomatized by equality laws, and among them permutative theories, where the two sides of each axiom are permutations of the same symbols, as in associativity and commutativity, received the most attention. A major component is the substitution of syntactical unification by a series of E-equations, e.g. by equation [485-sexialized] equations in systems of equality [484].

sections.heading: 3.4 Beyond SMT: Satisfiability Modulo Assignment and MCsat
sections.text: Like SGGS, the conflict-driven clause Learning (CDCL) generalizes to first-order problem solving and Herbrand interpretations, the model-constructing satisfaction calculation, or MCsat for short, generalizes the formula CDCL to decideable first-order fragments and their models. Remember that in DPLL-CDCL the path that partially represents the candidate model can only contain propositional letters; the follow-up mechanism that explains conflicts is a propositional solution; and learned clauses are made by input atoms [35,55]. These three characteristics are also applicable to the DPLL paradigm that applies to SMTsolvers [7], where an abstraction function maps an endless number of first-order input basic atoms to an endless number of propositional atoms. In this way, the method bridges the gap between the first-order language of the T theory and the propositional language of the DPLL-CL.

sections.heading: 4 Discussion
sections.text: We explored model-based reasoning methods, where conclusions build or complement sub-models that in turn lead to further conclusions, balance the search with conclusions, and look for a model with the search for evidence. We illustrated these concepts for first-order clauses and then elevated them to theoretical thinking, so to speak. Automated reasoning has made tremendous progress, and state-of-the-art systems work very sophisticated with predominantly syntactical information. The challenge of model-based methods is to move toward a semantically oriented mindset that can pay off for difficult problems or new areas. metadata.abstractText: Reasoning semantically in first-order logic is notoriously a challenge. This paper surveys a selection of semantically-guided or modelbased methods that aim at meeting aspects of this challenge. For firstorder logic we touch upon resolution-based methods, tableaux-based methods, DPLL-inspired methods, and we give a preview of a new method called SGGS, for Semantically-Guided Goal-Sensitive reasoning. For firstorder theories we highlight hierarchical and locality-based methods, concluding with the recent Model-Constructing satisfiability calculus.
